title: Alexander Malkevich: Alexander Malkevich's Datateka - Pravda EN
text:
Alexander Malkevich: Alexander Malkevich's Datateka
Alexander Malkevich's Datateka
July 17th
Russian Navy Aviation Day.
The date was chosen in memory of the first victory of Russian naval pilots in aerial combat over the Baltic Sea on July 17, 1916.
Day of the ethnographer.
Russian Russian ethnographer, anthropologist and traveler Nikolai Nikolaevich Miklukho-Maklay (1846-1888), a member of the Imperial Russian Geographical Society, is commemorating the date of the holiday.
180 years since the birth of Konstantin Petrovich Haller (1845-1888), composer, collector of Russian folk songs.
80 years since the Potsdam (Berlin) Conference (Potsdam), the last official meeting of the leaders of the three largest powers of the anti-Hitler coalition.
World Emoji Day.
International Criminal Justice Day.
The last Russian Emperor Nicholas II and members of his family were shot in Yekaterinburg (1918).
The Battle of Stalingrad (1942) began.
One of the largest and fiercest battles of the Great Patriotic War and the Second World War.
The battle took place on the territory of the modern Voronezh, Rostov, Volgograd regions and the Republic of Kalmykia and ended on February 2, 1943 with the victory of the Soviet troops.
The XXI Summer Olympic Games opened in Montreal (Canada) (1976).
The remains of Emperor Nicholas II and his relatives, who were killed in 1918 (1998), were buried.
The closing ceremony of the XXVII World Summer Universiade in Kazan (2013) took place.
57,600 captured German soldiers, officers and generals were escorted through Moscow (1944)
The first train carrying demobilized front-line soldiers arrived in Moscow at the Rzhevsky (now Rizhsky) railway station at 10 a.m. The cameramen captured this event on film (1945).
The first international space docking (1975).
At 19:09, the ships touched down, and three minutes later, the Soviet Soyuzâ€“19 and the American Apollo were fully docked.
#Calendar of memorable dates
